Presenting Problem / Chief Complaint: The patient expresses a desire to finish their insurance courses by the end of the month and plans to schedule dedicated study time each day to achieve this goal.
History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient has been experiencing emotional ups and downs but feels more motivated lately, attributing this to having goals and making progress. They also reflect on missing their mother and coping by remembering good times.
Risk Assessment: The patient feels nervous yet excited about attending a local art class, recognizing the normalcy of these feelings.
Mental Health Observations: The patient reports feeling more confident in their understanding of study material and overall motivation.
Physiological Observations: The patient notes improved sleep quality after practicing mindfulness exercises.
Current Functional Status: The patient is actively integrating mindfulness into their routine and breaking down study material into manageable sections, leading to a sense of progress.
Progress Evaluation: The patient shows positive shifts in motivation and emotional well-being, indicating effective coping strategies.
Therapeutic Interventions: The patient is encouraged to write about their feelings regarding their mother as a therapeutic exercise.
Next Steps: The patient plans to write about their mother this week and continue with their study schedule.
